ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Professor Jaffe's course needs much more structure. The lessons were all over the place, and often devolved into irrelevant discussions sparked by students with very niche interests.
The professor is a fantastic professor. She is very knowledgeable in her field, petroleum geopolitics.
Begging part of the class was well prepared, however, as the course goes by, the lecture was disorganized and I was not able to gain comprehensive knowledge about the U.S energy policy.

Question 3. Work for the midterm, in-class activity, and final were extremely time consuming and/or required a lot of preparation relative to the material covered in class. Concepts from the readings were not often covered, so we were left to work through new material on our own. Question 10. Professor Jaffe was very engaging and personable, but class time was not structured well, and very little material was covered in a meaningful way. It was disappointing to have so much class time spent watching film clips, or going over the requirements for assignments due. It also often felt like we were simply trying to take up time until the end of class.
the expectation for the class was high but the instructor did not meet it. Her teaching are unclear, not well taught out - not Yale graduate standard

I loved how Professor Jaffe used a lot of her own extensive experience in the energy industry to highlight the changing policies and circumstances of the energy industry. She would tell us these amazing stories of what happened during OPEC meetings, etc. that really made me much more interested in understanding the energy industry. While some people may have saw this as distracting--it gave us a first hand look at how some energy decision are made, which is critical to know.

Re: the pace of the course: The amount of material the course sought to cover was ambitious given that this was only a 2 credit course, but then the pace of discussion in class was too slow to actually cover most of it. Out of class assignments were extensive, but in-class time was informal and not always very informative. A student would have had to do a lot of self-teaching and extra learning outside of class readings in not very much time to build up the background needed to really get a lot out of the class assignments. The title is somewhat misleading. The course was less about emerging energy issues and more about the history of Middle East geopolitics, with the focus almost exclusively on petrol.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Lectures, Assignments and the OPEC Game.
Get the sense of the US energy policy and how oil price is influenced by geopolitics factors.
The professor shared her professional experience quite frequently, which I found to be the most valuable component of the course.
The course allowed students to practice speaking in front of a group. Also, professor Jaffe has many fantastic stories about her previous work.

I really enjoyed the course because it played upon different energy scenarios and how countries may respond. It really gave me a good insight on how oil prices are determined and how that can impact energy security for the US.
Jaffe has been in the business a long time - she has a wealth of knowledge and is happy to share it. The

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Structure of the course and the manner in which it is taught.
Clarify the key message - It was not clear what the instructor wanted to tell us
Lectures should be planned more in advance, and emphasis should be placed on making best use of class time.

There is not much to be gained from taking this class. The professor is kind but does not have in-depth knowledge of the subject matter. Professor Jaffe would have been fantastic had she been teaching a course on journalism but that we were focused on energy policy did not play to her strengths.
instructor teaching material
Perhaps more guest lecturers.

The classroom was poorly managed. The lectures weren't so much lectures as a series of personal stories. While many were interesting, I was more interested in learning about energy policy. Conversations were often only between a few people without much direction to increase participation from other students. Classroom time management was lacking.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: OPEC game was helpful to understand the prospect of the oil producing countries and factors that would affect oil price.
Not much relationship after the first few classes.
discussion sessions were horrible, not well managed and incoherent agenda opec simulation game could be way better organized - not much learning from that group exercise

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: The course has given me a solid foundation in petroleum geopolitics.
Energy and oil industry-related concepts are important concepts to add to energy knowledge base.
This course was far too introductory to give students much more knowledge of energy issues had they taken any of the other energy classes at F&ES.

It is important to know this because energy prices can impact climate change and emissions. So if you're interested in climate change, it's relevant because these things will determine the use of alternative energies in the future. Also, it will impact environmental stewardship in the energy industry.

I was hoping that this course would supplement other energy and policy courses I had taken. While it did in that my other courses did not have an explicit focus on Oil, I think I learned just as much from other students in the class as I did from the instructor and I'm not sure I am equipped to do anything with the knowledge I gained.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took the course because of my interest in energy issues in the 21st century.
I wanted to understand how energy policy is influenced by other factors including politics, oil price and technological innovations.
To enhance my understanding of the oil industry and policy issues
I had hoped to gain insight into US energy policy issues.
taught it will a good class for students focusing on energy
To understand energy policy and how that can impact environmental issues like climate change.
It looked interesting.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
moderately. The information was useful and I will reference the readings as I need, but I feel the course could have made better use of class time to maximize value to students.
No. See answer to question 17.
i managed to get some context but not much tangible learning
Yes, it exceeded them. This was by far my most favorite course of the semester. I loved the heavy interaction of the class, the movies, the discussions and homework.
Not really.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The group work reinforced my learning in the concepts taught in class.
N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Don't take this course unless there are significant changes to the way in which it is taught. It was a whirlwind of work, with little to no instruction.
It is a very good class.
Some of the course was well prepared and the template of the white paper was really helpful.

Please do not offer this course as is again. There are too few energy courses at F&ES for the amount of interest as is so more resources should be put into developing great classes. However, this course, while adding to the list offered, may discourage people from studying within the school.
just don't unless it is dramatically improved
Take it if you're interested in energy politics, both domestically and internationally, and how it can impact environmental issues related to oil/gas, etc.
If you have a particular reason to get to know Amy Jaffe, go for it. Otherwise, you may be better off in another energy course.
